page.title: 15Lock Museum _Willenhall
page.content: The presence of coal, iron and limestone in the Black Country gave rise to the metal trades for which it was famous. By the eighteenth century the towns of Wolverhampton, Willenhall and Bilston made most of the countries locks. In the nineteenth century Willenhall became an international centre for lockmaking, which it still is today. The museum in New Road is an example of a typical small lockmaking premises. Apart from a house there is a lockmakers workshop at the rear. The museum tries to show the progress of lockmaking from the blacksmith's art to the highly mechanised industry of today. Visitors can participate in making locks by hand, and learn durectly from the local craftsmen,keeping alive local history.
